moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Nf3 Bg4 4. Be2: This "passive" approach by White actually is quite effective, and transposes to comparably good variations of a QGD after counterattacking the Queen.
moves.4... c6 5. d4 e6 6. O-O Nf6 7. c4: Both Black and White have been working towards a favorable transposition. Here Black has gotten his bad bishop out but White is now pushing back.
moves.7... Qd8 8. Nc3 Bb4: Probably not as effective now that there is no pin.
moves.12. Bh4: Bh4!? White would have done well to take the Knight (BxN) and win the b pawn. White was trying to hold on to the bishop and provoke king weaknesses instead.
moves.12... b6: The dark square bishop is already missed. Black would like to play ...Qc7 but would face Bg3.
moves.14. g4 Bg6 15. Ne5: White was playing for this position.
moves.15... c5: Black saves the pawn but the kingside is now weakened.
moves.16. Nxg6 fxg6 17. Bd3 g5 18. Bg6+ Ke7 19: White wants to control the d-file.
moves.21... Re8: ...Re1? accomplishes little because the rook can be driven off by the bishop, and the d-file pin is now a concern. Better was probably Qc8, defending c5 and e6.
moves.22. Bg6 Rh8 23. dxc5 Qc8 24. Bd6+ Kd8 25: Black is behind a couple pawns but of more concern is the king position.
moves.27. Rd2 Kc8 28. c5: White's plan is to advance the pawn to tie down Black's pieces first.
moves.28... Nd5 29. c6 Nc5 30. Qc4 Na4: Black is in trouble but appears to have lots of fight yet. But the king position is already fatal, which White immediately demonstrates..
moves.31. Rxd5: 31 Rxd5!! shatters Black's position. Qe4! would also win but more slowly after ...Nc7.
moves.31... exd5: If... Nb6, Qe4! NxR, Qe6  leads to a similar end to the game.
moves.32. Bf5+: No need to worry about the Queen, Black is now caught in a mating net.
moves.32... Kd8 33. c7+: A key move...blocking Black's Queen from defending against checks, and checkmate can't be avoided after ...Ke8 (forced) Qc6 !
moves.35... Kg8: Otherwise, if ...Kf6, 36 Qe6 is also checkmate.
